content:
In HoTT, would it be consistent for the identity type a=Ab a =_A b a=A​b to always live one universe below A A A?

For many types, this works already:

  • Un:Un+1 U_n : U_{n+1} Un​:Un+1​. But X=UnY X =_{U_n} Y X=Un​​Y is equivalent to (f:X→Y)×((y:Y)→isContr(fiber(f))) (f : X \to Y) \times ((y : Y) \to \mathrm{isContr}(\mathrm{fiber}(f))) (f:X→Y)×((y:Y)→isContr(fiber(f))), so we can certainly put it in Un U_n Un​.
  • Let A:Un,B:A→Un A : U_n, B : A \to U_n A:Un​,B:A→Un​. Then (a1,b1)=(a:A)×B(a)(a2,b2) (a_1,b_1) =_{(a : A) \times B(a)} (a_2,b_2) (a1​,b1​)=(a:A)×B(a)​(a2​,b2​) is equivalent to (p:a1=Aa2)×subst(B,p,b1)=B(a2)b2 (p : a_1 =_A a_2) \times subst(B,p,b_1) =_{B(a_2)} b_2 (p:a1​=A​a2​)×subst(B,p,b1​)=B(a2​)​b2​. So if A A A and B B B have identity types in Un−1 U_{n-1} Un−1​, so can (a:A)×B(a)(a : A) \times B(a)(a:A)×B(a).
  • et cetera.

But this doesn't automatically work for function types. Let A:Un A : U_n A:Un​ and B:A→UnB : A \to U_n B:A→Un​. Then f=(a:A)→B(a)g f =_{(a : A) \to B(a)} g f=(a:A)→B(a)​g is equivalent to (a:A)→f(a)=B(a)g(a) (a : A) \to f(a) =_{B(a)} g(a) (a:A)→f(a)=B(a)​g(a). But even if A A A and B B B have identity types in Un−1 U_{n-1} Un−1​, this still lives in UnU_nUn​.

This would work if the universes were impredicative. But then again, nested impredicative universes are inconsistent anyway, or so I've heard.

I imagine it's possible to construct a counterexample to this, e.g. by a higher inductive type with a point and a loop at the point for every element of a universe Un\mathcal U_nUn​. But I'm not sure.

This feels impossible to me. However, there is a weaker version of it which is possible. If we assume propositional resizing (see the end of Section 3.5 of the HoTT book), then every mere proposition is equivalent to a mere proposition in the bottom universe. Therefore, for any type which happens to be a set, its identity types will all be equivalent to types at the bottom universe (again, assuming propositional resizing).

Elaborating on @Tom de Jong's idea, I think we can construct a counterexample as follows.

Assume that we have enough higher inductive types to construct suspensions of arbitrary types, and that constructing the suspension does not raise the universe level. (See HoTT book section 6.5 for the definition of suspension.) Thus, if A:UiA : \mathcal{U}_iA:Ui​, then ΣA:Ui\Sigma A : \mathcal{U}_iΣA:Ui​. Let A:UiA : \mathcal{U}_iA:Ui​ be a type which is not equivalent to any type in Ui−1\mathcal{U}_{i-1}Ui−1​. Then ΣA\Sigma AΣA is a type in Ui\mathcal{U}_iUi​, but its path type N=ΣASN =_{\Sigma A} SN=ΣA​S is equivalent to AAA, therefore it is not equivalent to any type in Ui−1\mathcal{U}_{i-1}Ui−1​ since AAA isn't.

EDIT: @Tom de Jong Pointed out that this is not correct. Thanks!

@Ben Logsdon It's not true that N=ΣASN =_{\Sigma A} SN=ΣA​S is equivalent to AAA. E.g., if AAA has decidable equality, then we can characterise π1(ΣA)\pi_1(\Sigma A)π1​(ΣA) as the type of certain lists of elements of AAA.

However, you can do some related things. With HITs we can also construct Eilenberg-MacLane spaces: for any set (i.e. 0-type) GGG with a group structure, there is a type BGBGBG with a point ⋆\star⋆ such that ⋆=BG⋆\star =_{BG} \star⋆=BG​⋆ is equivalent to GGG. So we will have a counterexample as soon as there is a group in Ui\mathcal{U}_iUi​ that is not equivalent to any type in Ui−1\mathcal{U}_{i-1}Ui−1​. The first such GGG that occurs to me is the surreal numbers under addition, but probably there is a simpler one.

Thanks @Mike Shulman. There is work by @Martín Hötzel Escardó with Marc Bezem, Thierry Coquand and Peter Dybjer where they show:

For any universe 𝓤, there is a group in the successor universe 𝓤⁺ which is not isomorphic to any group in 𝓤.

https://www.cs.bham.ac.uk/~mhe/TypeTopology/Groups.FreeOverLargeLocallySmallSet.html
Specifically, they show: if there is a large, locally small set, then there is a large group. We can then instantiate this with the large, locally small set of ordinals.
This is the first time I've seen anyone mention the Eilenberg-Mac Lane space of the surreal numbers!
